Dear Tajuanda Latriece Carey:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/14/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
• (1) An initial health screening shall be completed
for each resident within 24 hours of admission to
a facility.
Three of three youth case files reviewed, failed to document the completion of an
initial health screening within 24 hours of admission.
2

CCI Rule 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(2) An institution shall have the following documentation
of an admission physical examination for each resident,
unless an earlier examination is medically indicated:
(b) For a resident 3 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 1 year
prior to admission or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after admission.
One of three youth case files reviewed failed to document the completion of a
physical examination within 1 year prior to admission or a new physical
examination within 30 calendar days after admission.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency did not require technical assistance at this time.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency did not request consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000120 with CAP approval date of 02/24/2025 was a
result of the agency staff's failure to respond with appropriate behavior management,
provide proper supervision and administer medication as prescribed. The agency has
successfully completed the action steps of the CAP.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
2024 Interim Audit: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting period as a
result of the Interim inspection completed on 01/20/2025. The report contained the following
violations: Four of nine employee files reviewed failed to document the completion of a
criminal history clearance as required prior to the start of employment; Two of three files
reviewed failed to document that the grievance policy was provided to residents and
families at the time of admission; One of three reports reviewed did not have a supervisor
signature on the initial treatment plan; Two of three cases reviewed did not have the
3

signature of the social service worker on the updated treatment plan; and One of three
cases reviewed did not have the signature of the supervisor on the updated treatment plan.
The CAP contained action items to resolve areas of non-compliance and promote ongoing
compliance for the agency.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000466 with CAP approval date of 07/15/2025 was a
result of the agency’s failure to notify DCWL of law enforcement contact with youth in
the program. The agency has submitted an acceptable corrective action plan and is
working toward compliance.
Beverly House has one additional special investigation report with CAP Pending.
Special Investigation report 2025SIC0000873 was approved on 09/04/2025 and is a
result of the agency failing to notify DCWL of the AWOL of a youth.
Financial Overview
Beverly House is operated under Spectrum Human Services. Spectrum Human Service
Inc. is a 501(c)3. Their financial audit was reviewed and found fiscally sound.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was received and reviewed on 08/26/2025.
Assessment indicates there were not any barriers or systemic factors impacting rule
compliance. Beverly House staff continue to work toward enhancing
treatment for youth in the program and specifically motivating the youth to attend and
participate in clinical intervention. The agency has been working with local law
enforcement to improve the working relationship and provide education regarding CCI
policies and procedures in hopes to increase the understanding and collaboration.
Staff and Youth Interviews
A total of four staff were interviewed. The direct care staff spoke positively regarding
their employment with the agency and working with youth in the program. The staff
shared some of the challenges associated with working at the facility, however
expressed the ability to continue due to commitment to the youth. Staff were
knowledgeable about the policy and procedures for Beverly House, and all felt the
training provided/required by the agency has been helpful. No concerns were reported.
Three youth were interviewed at Beverly House as a part of the Interim inspection. The
youth provided positive feedback about the program and interactions with staff. Youth
4

did express challenges in peer relationships but confirmed that staff encourage
appropriate peer conflict/resolution. No areas of concern were reported by the youth.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through was completed and the agency was found to be in well maintained.
There is one youth in the home that has struggled with maintaining the cleanliness of her
room. The agency continues to work with the resident to address this issue.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
